    \section{Classifying Images with Deep Convolutional Neural
Networks}\label{classifying-images-with-deep-convolutional-neural-networks}

    In the previous chapter, we looked in depth at different aspects of the
TensorFlow API, became familiar with tensors, naming variables, and
operators, and learned how to work with variable scopes. In this
chapter, we will now learn about \textbf{Convolutional Neural Networks
(CNNs)}, and how we can implement CNNs in TensorFlow. We will also take
an interesting journey in this chapter and we apply this type of deep
neural network architecture to image classification.

So we will start by discussing the basic building blocks of CNNs, using
a bottom-up approach. Then we will take a deeper dive into the CNN
architecture and how to implement deep CNNs in TensorFlow. Along the way
we will be covering the following topics:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Understanding convolution operations in one or two dimensions
\item
  Learning about the building blocks of CNN architectures
\item
  Implementing deep convolutional neural networks in TensorFlow
\end{itemize}

    \section{Building blocks of convolutional neural
networks}\label{building-blocks-of-convolutional-neural-networks}

    Convolutional neural networks, or CNNs, are a family of models that were
inspired by how the visual cortex of human brain works when recognizing
objects.

The development of CNNs goes back to the 1990's, when Yann LeCun and his
colleagues proposed a novel neural network architecture for classifying
handwritten digits from images.

Due to the outstanding performance of CNNs for image classification
tasks, they have gained a lot of attention and this led to tremendous
improvements in machine learning and computer vision applications.

In the following sections, we next see how CNNs are used as feature
extraction engines, and then we will delve into the theoretical
definition of convolution and computing convolution in one and two
dimensions.

    \subsection{Understanding CNNs and learning feature
hierarchies}\label{understanding-cnns-and-learning-feature-hierarchies}

    Successfully extrating \textbf{salient (relevant) features} is key to
the performance of any machine learning algorithm, of course, and
traditional machine learning models rely on input features that may come
from a domain expert, or are based on computational feature extraction
techniques. Neural networks are able to automatically learn the features
from raw data that are most useful for a particular task. For this
reason, it is common to consider a neural network as a feature
extraction engine: the early layers (those right after the input layer)
extract \textbf{low-level features}.

Multilayer neural networks, and in particular, deep convolutional neural
networks, construct a so-called \textbf{feature hierarchy} by combining
the low-level features in a layer-wise fashion to form high-level
features. For example, if we are dealing with images, then low-level
features, such as edges and blobs, are extracted from the earlier
layers, which are combined together to form high-level features - as
object shapes like a building, a car, or a dog.

As you can see in the following image, a CNN computes \textbf{feature
maps} from an input image, where each element comes from a local patch
of pixel in the input image:

    This local patch of pixels is referred to as the \textbf{local receptive
field}. CNNs will usually perform very well for image-related tasks, and
that is largely due to two important ideas:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Sparse-connectivity}: A single element in the feature map is
  connected to only a small patch of pixels. (This is very different
  from connecting to the whole input image, in the case of perceptrons.
  You may find it useful to look back and compare how we implemented a
  fully connected network that connected to the whole image).
\item
  \textbf{Parameter-sharing}: The same weights are used for different
  patches of the input image.
\end{itemize}

As a direct consequence of these two ideas, the number of weights
(parameters) in the network decreases dramatically, and we see an
improvement in the ability to capture \textbf{salient} features.
Intuitively, it makes sense that nearby pixels are probably more
relevant to each other than pixels that are far away from each other.

Typically, CNNs are composed for several \textbf{Convolutional (conv)}
layers and subsampling (also known as \textbf{Pooling (P)}) layers that
are followed by one or more \textbf{Fully Connected (FC)} layers at the
end. The fully connected layers are essentially a multilayer perceptron,
where every input unit \(i\) is connected to every output unit \(j\)
with weight \(w_{ij}\).

Please note that subsampling layers, commonly known as \textbf{pooling
layers}, do not have any learnable parameters; for instance, there are
no weights or bias units in pooling layers. However, both convolution
and fully connected layers have such weights and biases.

In the following sections, we will study convolutional and pooling
layers in more detail and see how they work. To understand how
convolution operations work ,let's start with a convolution in one
dimension before working through the typical two-dimensional cases as
applications for two-dimensional images later.

    \subsection{Performing discrete
convolutions}\label{performing-discrete-convolutions}

    A \textbf{discrete convolution} (or simply \textbf{convolution}) is a
fundamental operation in a CNN. Therefore, it is important to understand
how this operation works. In this section, we will learn the
mathematical definition and discuss some of the \textbf{naive}
algorithms to compute convolutions of two one-dimensional vectors or two
two-dimensional matrices.

Please note that this description is solely for understanding how a
convolution works. Indeed, much more efficient implementations of
convolutional operations already exist in packages such as TensorFlow,
as we will see later in this chapter.

In this chapter, we will use subscripts to denote the size of a
multidimensional array; for example, \(A_{n_1 \times n_2}\) is a
two-dimensional array of size \(n_1 \times n_2\). We use brackets \([]\)
to denote the indexing of a multidimensional array. For example,
\(A[i, j]\) means the element at index \(i, j\) of matrix \(A\).
Furthermore, note that we use a special symbol \(*\) to denote the
convolution operation between two vectors or matrices, which is not to
be confused with the multiplication operator \(*\) in Python.

    \subsubsection{Performing a discrete convolution in one
dimension}\label{performing-a-discrete-convolution-in-one-dimension}

    Let's start with some basic definitions and notations we are going to
use. A discrete convolution for two one-dimensional vectors \(x\) and
\(w\) is denoted by \(y = x * w\), in which vector \(x\) is our input
(sometimes called \textbf{signal}) and \(w\) is called the
\textbf{filter} or \textbf{kernel}. A discrete convolution is
mathematically defined as follows:

\[y = x * w \rightarrow y[i] = \sum_{k=-\infty}^{+\infty} x[i-k]w[k]\]

Here, the brackets \([]\) are used to denote the indexing for vector
elements. The index \(i\) runs through each element of the output vector
\(y\). There are two odds things in the preceding formula that we need
to clarify: \(-\infty\) to \(+\infty\) indices and negative indexing for
\(x\).

    \paragraph{Cross-correlation}\label{cross-correlation}

    Cross-correlation (or simply correlation) between the input vector and a
filter is denoted by \(y = x * w\) and is very much like a sibling for a
convolution with a small difference; the difference is that in
cross-correlation, the multiplication is performed in the same
direction. Therefore, it is not required to rotate the filter matrix
\(w\) in each dimension. Mathematically, cross-correlation is defined as
follows:

\[y = x * w \rightarrow y[i] = \sum_{k=-\infty}^{+\infty} x[i+k]w[k]\]

The same rules for padding and stride may be applied to
cross-correlation as well.

The first issue where the sum runs through indices from \(-\infty\) to
\(+\infty\) seems odd mainly because in machine learning applications,
we always deal with finite feature vectors. For example, if \(x\) has 10
features with indices \(0, 1, \ldots, 9\), then indices \(-\infty: -1\)
and \(10: +\infty\) are out of bounds for \(x\). Therefore, to correctly
compute the summation shown in the preceding formula, it is assumed that
\(x\) and \(w\) are filled with zeros. This will result in an output
vector \(y\) that also has infinite size with lots of zeros as well.
Since this is not useful in practical situations, \(x\) is padded only
with a finite number of zeros.

This process is called \textbf{zero-padding} or simply \textbf{padding}.
Here, the number of zeros padded on each side is denoted by \(p\). An
example padding of a one-dimensional vector \(x\) is shown in the
following figure:

    Let's assume that the original input \(x\) and filter \(w\) have \(n\)
and \(m\) elements, respectively, where \(m \le n\). Therefore, the
padded vector \(x^p\) has size \(n + 2p\). Then, the practical formula
for computing a discrete convolution will change to the following:

\[y = x * w \rightarrow y[i] = \sum_{k=0}^{k=m-1} x^p[i+m-k]w[k]\]

Now that we have solved the infinite index issue, the second issue is
indexing \(x\) with \(i+m-k\). The important point to notice here is
that \(x\) and \(w\) are indexed in different directions in this
summation. For this reason, we can flip one of those vectors, \(x\) or
\(w\), after they are padded. Then, we can simply compute their dot
product.

Let's assume we flip the filter \(w\) to get the rotated filter \(w^r\).
Then, the dot product \(x[i:i+m].w^r\) is computed to get one element
\(y[i]\), where \(x[i:i+m]\) is a patch of \(x\) with size \(m\).

This operation is repeated like in a sliding window approach to get all
the output elements. The following figure provides an example with
\(x = [3, 2, 1, 7, 1, 2, 5, 4]\) and
\(w = [\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{4}, 1, \frac{1}{4}]\) so that the first
three output elements are computed:

    You can see in the preceding example that the padding size is zero
(\(p=0\)). Notice that the rotated filter \(w^r\) is shifted by two
cells each time we shift. This \textbf{shift} is another hyperparameter
of a convolution, the \textbf{stride} s. In this example, the stride is
two, \(s=2\). Note that the stride has to be a positive number smaller
than the size of the input vector. We will talk more about padding and
strides in the next section.

    \paragraph{The effect of zero-padding in a
convolution}\label{the-effect-of-zero-padding-in-a-convolution}

    So far here, we have used zero-padding in convolutions to compute
finite-sized output vectors. Technically, padding can be applied with
any \(p \ge 0\). Depending on the choice \(p\), boundary cells may be
treated differently than the cells localed in the middle of \(x\).

Now consider an example where \(n=5, m=3\). Then, \(p=0, x[0]\) is only
used in computing one output element (for instance, \(y[0]\)), while
\(x[1]\) is used in the computation of two output elements (for
instance, \(y[0]\) and \(y[1]\)). So, you can see that this different
treatment of elements of \(x\) can artificially put more emphasis on the
middle element, \(x[2]\), since it has appeared in most computations. We
can avoid this issue if we choose \(p=2\), in which case, each element
of \(x\) will be involved in computing three elements of \(y\).

Furthermore, the size of the output \(y\) also depends on the choice of
the padding strategy we use. There are three modes of padding that are
commonly used in practice: \textbf{full}, \textbf{same}, and
\textbf{valid}:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  In the \textbf{full} mode, the padding parameter \(p\) is set to
  \(p=m-1\). Full padding increases the dimensions of the output; thus,
  it is rarely used in convolutional neural network architectures.
\item
  \textbf{Same} padding is usually used if you want to have the size of
  the output the same as the input vector \(x\). In this case, the
  padding parameter \(p\) is computed according to the filter size,
  along with the requirement that the input size and output size are the
  same.
\item
  Finally, computing a convolution in the \textbf{valid} mode refers to
  the case where \(p=0\) (no padding).
\end{itemize}

The following figure illustrates the three different padding modes for a
simple \(5 \times 5\) pixel input with a kernel size of \(3 \times 3\)
and a stride of 1:

    The most commonly used padding mode in convolutional neural networks is
\textbf{same} padding. One of its advantage over the other padding modes
is that same padding preserves the height and width of the input images
or tensors, which makes designing a network architecture more
convenient.

One big disadvantage of the \textbf{valid} padding versus \textbf{full}
and \textbf{same} padding, for example, is that the volume of the
tensors would decrease substantially in neural networks with many
layers, which can be detrimental to the network performance.

In practice, it is recommended that you preserve the spatial size using
same padding for the convolutional layers and decrease the spatial size
via pooling layers instead. As for the full padding, its size results in
an output larger than the input size. Full padding is usually used in
signal processing applications where it is important to minimize
boundary effects. However, in deep learning context, boundary effect is
not usually an issue, so we rarely see full padding.

    \paragraph{Determining the size of the convolution
output}\label{determining-the-size-of-the-convolution-output}

    The output size of a convolution is determined by the total number of
times hat we shift the filter \(w\) along the input vector. Let's assume
that the input vector has size \(n\) and the filter is of size \(m\).
Then, the size of the output resulting from \(x*m\) with padding \(p\)
and stride \(s\) is determined as follows:

\[o = \left\lfloor \frac{n+2p-m}{s} \right\rfloor + 1\]

Here, \(\lfloor\rfloor\) denotes the floor operation.

Consider the following two cases:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Compute the output size for an input vector of size 10 with a
  convolution kernel of size 5, padding 2, and stride 1:
  \[n=10,m=5,p=2,s=1 \rightarrow o = \left\lfloor \frac{10+2.2-5}{1} \right\rfloor + 1 = 10\]
  (Note that in this case, the output size turns out to be the smae as
  the input; therefore, we conclude this as \textbf{mode='same'}).
\item
  How can the output size change for the same input vector, but have a
  kernel of size 3, and stride 2?
  \[n=10,m=3,p=2,s=2 \rightarrow o = \left\lfloor \frac{10+2.2-3}{2} \right\rfloor + 1 = 6\]
\end{itemize}

Finally, in order to learn how to compute convolutions in one dimension,
a naive implementation is shown in the following code block, and the
results are compared with the \emph{numpy.convolve} function. The code
is as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

        \PY{k}{def} \PY{n+nf}{conv1d}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{x}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{w}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{p}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{s}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
            \PY{n}{w\PYZus{}rot} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{array}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{w}\PY{p}{[}\PY{p}{:}\PY{p}{:}\PY{o}{\PYZhy{}}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}

    So far, here, we have explored the convolution in 1D. We started with 1D
case to make the concepts easier to understand. In the next section, we
will extend this to two dimensions,

    \subsubsection{Performing a discrete convolution in
2D}\label{performing-a-discrete-convolution-in-2d}

    The concepts you learned in the previous sections are easily extendible
to two dimensions. When we deal with two-dimensional input, such as
matrix \(X_{n_1 \times n_2}\) and the filter matrix
\(W_{m_1 \times m_2}\), where \(m_1 \le n1\) and \(m_2 \le n_2\), then
the matrix \(Y = X * W\) is the result of 2D convolution of \(X\) and
\(W\). This is mathematically defined as follows:

\[Y = X * W \rightarrow Y[i, j] = \sum_{k1=-\infty}^{+\infty}\sum_{k2=-\infty}^{+\infty}X[i-k_1, j-k_2]W[k_1, k_2]\]

Notice that if you omit one of the dimensions, the remaining formula is
exactly the same as the one we used previously to compute the
convolution in 1D. In fact, all the previously mentioned techniques,
such as zero-padding, rotating the filter matrix, and the use of
strides, are also applicable to 2D convolutions, provided that they are
extended to both the dimensions independently. The following example
illustrates the computation of a 2D convolution between an input matrix
\(X_{3\times3}\), a kernel matrix \(W_{3\times3}\), padding
\(p=(1, 1)\), and stride \(s=(2, 2)\). According to the specified
padding, one layer of zeros are padded on each side of the input matrix,
which results in the padded matrix \(X_{5 \times 5}^{padded}\), as
follows:

    With the preceding filter, the rotate filter will be:

\[
W^r = 
\begin{bmatrix}
0.5 & 1.0 & 0.5 \\
0.1 & 0.4 & 0.3 \\
0.4 & 0.7 & 0.5
\end{bmatrix}
\]

Note that this rotation is not the same as the transpose matrix. To the
the rotated filter in NumPy, we can write \emph{W\_rot = W{[}::-1,
::-1{]}}. Next, we can shift the rotated filter matrix along the padded
input matrix \(X^{padded}\) like a sliding window and compute the sum of
the element-wise product, which is denoted by the \(\odot\) operator in
the following picture:

    The result will be the \(2 \times 2\) matrix \(Y\).

Let's also implement the 2D convolution according to the \textbf{naive}
algorithm described. The \emph{scipy.signal} package provides a way to
compute 2D convolution via the \emph{scipy.signal.convolve2d} function:

        \PY{n}{W} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{[}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{3}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,} \PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{2}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,} \PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{]}

    We provided a naive implementation to compute a 2D convolution for the
purpose of understand the concepts. However, this implementation is very
inefficient in terms of memory requirements and computational
complexity. Therefore, it should not be used in real-world neural
network applications.

In recent years, much more efficient algorithms have been developed that
use the Fourier transformation for computing convolutions. It is also
important to note that in the context of neural networks, the size of a
convolutional kernel is usually much smaller than the size of the input
image. For example, modern CNNs usually use kernel sizes such as
\(1 \times 1\), \(3 \times 3\) or \(5 \times 5\), for which efficient
algorithms have been designed that can carry out the convolutional
operations much more efficiently, such as the \textbf{Winograd's Minimal
Filtering} algorithm.

In the next section, we will discuss subsampling, which is another
important operation often used in CNNs.

    \subsection{Subsampling}\label{subsampling}

    Subsampling is typically applied in two forms of pooling operations in
convolutional neural networks: \textbf{max pooling} and
\textbf{mean-pooling} (also known as \textbf{average-pooling}).

The pooling layer is usually denoted by \(P_{n_1 \times n_2}\). Here,
the subscript determines the size of the neighborhodd (the number of
adjacent pixels in each dimension), where the max or mean operation is
performed. We refer to such a neighborhood as the \textbf{pooling size}.

The operation is described in the following figure. Here, max-pooling
takes the maximum value from a neighborhood of pixels, and mean-pooling
computes their average:

    The advantage of pooling is twofold:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  Pooling (max-pooling) introduces some sort of local invariance. This
  means that small changes in a local neighborhood do not change the
  result of max-pooling. Therefore, it helps generate features that are
  more robust to noise in the input data.
\item
  Pooling decreases the size of features, which results in higher
  computational efficiency. Furthermore, reducing the number of features
  may reduce the degree of overfitting as well.
\end{itemize}

Traditionally, pooling is assumed to be nonoverlapping. Pooling is
typically performed on nonoverlapping neighborhoods, which can be done
by setting the stride parameter equal to the pooling size. For example,
a nonoverlapping pooling layer \(P_{n_1 \times n_2}\) requires a stride
parameter \(s = (n_1, n_2)\). On the other hand, overlapping pooling
occurs if the stride is smaller than pooling size.

    \section{Putting everything together to build a
CNN}\label{putting-everything-together-to-build-a-cnn}

    So far, we have learned about the basic building blocks of convolutional
neural networks. The concepts illustrated in this chapter are not really
more difficult than traditional multilayer neural networks. Intuitively,
we can say that the most important operation in a traditional neural
network is matrix-vector multiplication.

For instance, we use matrix-vector multiplications to pre-activations
(or net input) as in \(a = Wx + b\). Here, \(x\) is a column vector
representing pixels, and \(W\) is the weight matrix connecting the pixel
inputs to each hidden unit. In convolutional neural network, this
operation is replaced by a convolution operation, as in
\(A = W * X + b\), where \(X\) is a matrix representing the pixels in a
height \(\times\) width arrangement. In both cases, the pre-activations
are passed to an activation function to obtain the activation of a
hidden unit \(H = \phi(A)\), where \(\phi\) is the activation function.
Furthermore, recall that subsampling is another building block of a
convolutional neural network, which may appear in the form of pooling,
as we described in the previous section.

    \subsection{Working with multiple input of color
channels}\label{working-with-multiple-input-of-color-channels}

    An input sample to a convolutional layer may contain one or more 2D
arrays or matrices with dimensions \(N_1 \times N_2\) (for example, the
image height and width in pixels). These \(N_1 \times N_2\) matrices are
called \textbf{channels}. Therefore, using multiple channels as input to
a convolutional layer requires us to use a rank-3 tensor or a
three-dimensional array: \(X_{N_1 \times N_2 \times C_{in}}\), where
\(C_{in}\) is the number of input channels. For example, let's consider
images as input to the first layer of a CNN. If the image is colored and
uses the RGB color mode, then \(C_{in} = 3\) (for the red, green, and
blue colors channels in RGB). However, if the image is in grayscale,
then we have \(C_{in} = 1\) because there is only one channel with the
grayscale pixel intensity values.

When we work with images, we can read images into NumPy arrays using the
\emph{'uint8'} (unsigned 8-bit integer) data type to reduce memory usage
compared to 16-bit, 32-bit, or 64-bit integer types, for example.
Unsigned 8-bit integers take values in the range {[}0, 255{]}, which are
sufficient to store the pixel information in RGB images, which also
takes values in the same range.

Next, let's look at an example of how we can read in an image into our
Python session using SciPy. However, please note that reading images
with SciPy requires that you have the \textbf{Python Imaging Library
(PIL)} package installed. We can install Pillow, a more user-friendly
for of PIL, to satisfy those requirements, by executing the command
\textbf{pip install pillow}.

Once Pillow is installed, we can use the \emph{imread} function from the
\emph{scipy.misc} module to read an RGB image:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}3}]:} \PY{k+kn}{import} \PY{n+nn}{scipy}\PY{n+nn}{.}\PY{n+nn}{misc}
        
        \PY{n}{img} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{scipy}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{misc}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{imread}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{./example\PYZhy{}image.png}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{mode}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{RGB}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}

    Now that we have familiarized ourselves with the structure of input
data, the next question is how can we incorporate multiple input
channels in the convolution operation that we discussed in the previous
sections?

The answer is very simple: we perform the convolution operation for each
channel separately and then add the results together using the matrix
summation. The convolution associated with each channel (\(c\)) has it
own kernel matrix \(W[:, :, c]\). The total pre-activation result is
computed in the following formula:

Given a sample \(X_{n_1 \times n_2 \times c_{in}}\), a kernel matrix
\(W_{m_1 \times m_2 \times cm}\), and bias value \(b\):

\[Y^{CONV} = \sum_{c=1}^{c_m}W[:, :, c] * X[:, :, c]\] pre-activation:
\(A = Y^{CONV} + b\) feature map: \(H = \phi(A)\)

The final result, \textbf{h}, is called a \textbf{feature map}. Usually,
a convolutional layer of a CNN has more than one feature map. If we use
multiple feature maps, the kernel tensor becomes four-dimensional:
\(width \times height \times C_{in} \times C_{out}\). Here, width
\(\times\) height is the kernel size, \(C_{in}\) is the number of input
channels, and \(C_{out}\) is the number of output feature maps. So, now
let's include the number of output features maps in the preceding
formula and update it as follows:

Given a sample \(X_{n_1 \times n_2 \times cm}\), a kernel matrix
\(W_{m_1 \times m_2 \times c_{in} \times c_{out}}\), and bias value
\(b_c_{out}\):

\[Y^{CONV}[:,:,k] = \sum_{c=1}^{c_{in}}W[:, :, c, k] * X[:, :, c]\]
pre-activation: \(A[:, :, k] = Y^{CONV}[:, :, k] + b[k]\) feature map:
\(H[:, :, k] = \phi(A[:, :, k])\)

To conclude our discussion of computing convolutions in the context of
neural networks, let's look at the example in the following figure that
shows a convolutional layer, followed by a pooling layer.

In this example, there are three input channels. The kernel tensor is
four-dimensional. Each kernel matrix is denoted as \(m_1 \times m_2\),
and there are three of them, one for each input channel. Furthermore,
there are five such kernels, accounting for five output feature maps.
Finally, there is a pooling layer for subsampling the feature maps, as
shown in the following figure:

    How many trainable parameters exists in the preceding example?

To illustrate the advantages of convolution, \textbf{parameter-sharing},
and \textbf{sparse-connectivity}, let's work through an example. The
convolutional layer in the network shown in the preceding figure is a
four-dimensional tensor. So, there are
\(m_1 \times m_2 \times 3 \times 5\) parameters associated with the
kernel. Furthermore, there is a bias vector for each output feature map
of the convolutional layer. Thus, the size of the bias vector is 5.
Pooling layers do not have any (trainable) parameters; therefore, we can
write the following: \(m_1 \times m_2 \times 3 \times 5 + 5\).

If input tensor is of size \(n_1 \times n_2 \times 3\), assuming that
the convolution is performed with \textbf{mode='same'}, then the output
feature maps would be of size \(n_1 \times n2 \times 5\). Note that this
number is much smaller than the case if we wanted to have a fully
connected layer instead of the convolution layer. In the case of a fully
connected layer, the number of parameters for the weight matrix to reach
the same number of output units would have been as follows:
\((n_1 \times n_2 \times 3) \times (n_1 \times n_2 \times 5) = (n_1 \times n_2)^2 \times 3 \times 5\).

Given that \(m_1 < n_1\) and \(m_2 < n_2\), we can see that the
difference in the number of trainable parameters is huge.

In the next section, we will talk about how to regularize a neural
network.

    \subsection{Regularizing a neural network with
dropout}\label{regularizing-a-neural-network-with-dropout}

    Choosing the size of a network, whether we are dealing with a
traditional (fully connected) neural network or a CNN, has always been a
challenging problem. For instance, the size of a weight matrix and the
number of layers need to be tuned to achieve a reasonably good
performance.

The \textbf{capacity} of a network refers to the level of complexity of
the function that it can learn. Small networks, networks with relatively
small number of parameters, have a low capacity and are therefore likely
to be \textbf{under fit}, resulting in poor performance since they
cannot learn the underlying structure of complex datasets.

Yet, very large networks may more easily result in \textbf{overfitting},
where the network will memorize the training data and do extremely well
on the training set while achieving poor performance on the held-out
test set. When we deal with real-world machine learning problems, we do
not know how large the network should be \textbf{a priori}.

One way to address this problem is to build a network with a relatively
large capacity (in practice, we want to choose a capacity that is
slightly larger than necessary) to do well on the training set. Then, to
prevent overfitting, we can apply one or multiple regulatization schemes
to achieve good generalization performance on new data, such as the
held-out test set. A popular choice for regularization is L2
regulatization, which we discussed previously in this book.

In recent years, another popular regularization technique called
\textbf{dropout} has emerged that works amazingly well for regularizing
(deep) neural networks.

Intuitively, dropout can be considered as the consensus (averaging) of
an ensemble of models. In ensemble learning, we train several models
independently. During prediction, we then use the consensus of all the
trained models. However, both training several models and collecting and
averaging the output of multiple models is computationally expensive.
Here, dropout offers a workaround with an efficient way to train many
models at once and compute their average predictions at test or
prediction time.

Dropout is usually applied to the hidden units of higher layers. During
the training phase of a neural network, a fraction of the hidden units
is \textbf{randomly} dropped at every iteration with probability
\(P_{drop}\) (or the keep probability \(p_{keep} = 1 - p_{drop}\)). This
dropout probability is determined by the user and the common choice is
\(p=0.5\). When dropping a certain fraction of input neurons, the
weights associated with the remaining neurons are rescaled to account
for the missing (dropped) neurons.

The effect of this random dropout forces the network to learn a
redundant representation of the data. Therefore, the network cannot rely
on an activation of any set of hidden units since they may be turned off
at any time during training and is forced to learn more general and
robust patterns from the data.

This random dropout can effectively prevent overfitting. The following
figure shows an example of applying dropout with probability \(p=0.5\)
during the training phase, thereby half of the neurons become inactive
randomly. However, during prediction, all neurons will contribute to
computing the pre-activations of the next layer.

    As shown here, one important point to remember is that units may drop
randomly during training only, while for the evaluation phase, all the
hidden units must be active. To ensure that the overall activations are
on the same scale during training and prediction, the activations of the
active neurons have to be scaled appropriately (for example, by halving
the activation if the dropout probability was set to \(p=0.5\)).

However, since it is inconvenient to always scale activations when we
make predictions in practice, TensorFlow and other tools scale the
activations during training (for example, by doubling the activations if
the dropout probability was set to \(p=0.5\)).

So, what is the relationship between dropout and ensemble learning?
Since we drop different hidden neurons at each iteration, effectively we
are training different models. When all these models are finally
trained, we set the keep probability to 1 and use all the hidden units.
This means we are taking the average activation from all the hidden
units.

    \section{Implementing a deep convolutional neural network using
TensorFlow}\label{implementing-a-deep-convolutional-neural-network-using-tensorflow}

    In Chapter 13, you may recall that we implemented a multilayer neural
network for handwritten digit recognition problems, using different API
levels of TensorFlow. You may also recall that we achieved about 97
percent accuracy.

So now, we want to implement a CNN to solve this same problem and see
its predictive power in classifying handwritten digits. Note that the
fully connected layers that we saw in the Chapter 13 were able to
perform well on this problem. However, in some applications, such as
reading blank account numbers from handwritten digits, even tiny
mistakes can be very costly. Therefore, it is crucial to reduce this
error as much as possible.

    \subsection{The multilayer CNN
architecture}\label{the-multilayer-cnn-architecture}

    The architecture of the network that we are going to implement is shown
in the following figure. The input is \(28 \times 28\) grayscale images.
Considering the number of channels (which is 1 for grayscale images) and
a batch of input images, the input tensor's dimensions will be batchsize
\(\times 28 \times 28 \times 1\).

The input data goes through two convolutional layers that have a kernel
size of \(5 \times 5\). The first convolution has 32 output feature
maps, and the second one has 64 output feature maps. Each convolution
layer is followed by a subsampling layer in the form of a max-pooling
operation.

Then a fully-connected layer passes the output to a second
fully-connected layer, which acts as the final \emph{softmax} output
layer. The architecture of the network that we are going to implement is
shown in the following figure:

    The dimensions of the tensors in each layer are as follows:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \textbf{Input}: \([\text{batch_size} \times 28 \times 28 \times 1]\)
\item
  \textbf{Conv\_1}:
  \([\text{batch_size} \times 24 \times 24 \times 32]\)
\item
  \textbf{Pooling\_1}:
  \([\text{batch_size} \times 12 \times 12 \times 32]\)
\item
  \textbf{Conv\_2}: \([\text{batch_size} \times 8 \times 8 \times 64]\)
\item
  \textbf{Pooling\_2}:
  \([\text{batch_size} \times 4 \times 4 \times 64]\)
\item
  \textbf{FC\_1}: \([\text{batch_size} \times 1024]\)
\item
  \textbf{FC\_2 and softmax layer}: \([\text{batch_size} \times 10]\)
\end{itemize}

We will implement this network using two APIs: the low-level TensorFlow
API and the TensorFlow Layers API. But first, let's define some helper
functions at the beginning of the next section.

data}\label{loading-and-preprocessing-data}

\emph{load\_mnist} to read the MNIST handwritten digit dataset. Now we
need to repeat the same procedure here as well, as follows:

        \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Validation: }\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}valid}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{shape}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y\PYZus{}valid}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{shape}\PY{p}{)}
        \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Test Set:   }\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{shape}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y\PYZus{}test}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{shape}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

    After we have loaded the data, we need a function for iterating through
mini-batches of data, as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}6}]:} \PY{k}{def} \PY{n+nf}{batch\PYZus{}generator}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{batch\PYZus{}size}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{64}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{shuffle}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{False}\PY{p}{,} 
                            \PY{n}{random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{None}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
            \PY{n}{idx} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{arange}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{y}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{shape}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}
            \PY{k}{if} \PY{n}{shuffle}\PY{p}{:}
                \PY{n}{rng} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{random}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{RandomState}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n}{rng}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{shuffle}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{idx}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n}{X} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{X}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{idx}\PY{p}{]}
                \PY{n}{y} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{y}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{idx}\PY{p}{]}
                
            \PY{k}{for} \PY{n}{i} \PY{o+ow}{in} \PY{n+nb}{range}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{X}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{shape}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{batch\PYZus{}size}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
                \PY{k}{yield} \PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{i}\PY{p}{:}\PY{n}{i}\PY{o}{+}\PY{n}{batch\PYZus{}size}\PY{p}{,} \PY{p}{:}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{i}\PY{p}{:}\PY{n}{i}\PY{o}{+}\PY{n}{batch\PYZus{}size}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    This function returns a generator with a tuple for a match of samples,
for instance, data \(X\) and labels \(y\). We then need to normalize the
data (mean centering and division by the standard deviation) for better
training and convergence.

We compute the mean of each feature using the training data
(\emph{X\_train}) and calculate the standard deviation across all
features. The reason why we do not compute the standard deviation for
each feature individually is because some features (pixel position) in
image datasets such as MNIST have a constant value of 255 across all
images corresponding to white pixels in a grayscale image.

A constant value across all samples indicates no variation, and
therefore, the standard deviation of those features will be zero, and a
result would yield the division-by-zero error, which is why we compute
the standard deviation from the \emph{X\_train} array using
\emph{np.std} without specifying an \emph{axis} argument:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}7}]:} \PY{n}{mean\PYZus{}vals} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{mean}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}train}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{axis}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{0}\PY{p}{)}
        \PY{n}{std\PYZus{}val} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{std}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}train}\PY{p}{)}
        
        \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}train\PYZus{}centered} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}train} \PY{o}{\PYZhy{}} \PY{n}{mean\PYZus{}vals}\PY{p}{)}\PY{o}{/}\PY{n}{std\PYZus{}val}
        \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}valid\PYZus{}centered} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}valid} \PY{o}{\PYZhy{}} \PY{n}{mean\PYZus{}vals}\PY{p}{)}\PY{o}{/}\PY{n}{std\PYZus{}val}
        \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test\PYZus{}centered} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test} \PY{o}{\PYZhy{}} \PY{n}{mean\PYZus{}vals}\PY{p}{)}\PY{o}{/}\PY{n}{std\PYZus{}val}
\end{Verbatim}


    Now we are ready to implement the CNN we just described. We will proceed
by implementing the CNN model in TensorFlow.

    \subsection{Implementing a CNN in the TensorFlow low-level
API}\label{implementing-a-cnn-in-the-tensorflow-low-level-api}

    For implementing a CNN in TensorFlow, first we define two wrapper
functions to make the process of building the network simpler: a wrapper
function for a convolutional layer and a function for building a fully
connected layer.

The first function for a convolution layer is as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}8}]:} \PY{k+kn}{import} \PY{n+nn}{tensorflow} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n+nn}{tf}
        \PY{k+kn}{import} \PY{n+nn}{numpy} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n+nn}{np}
        
        \PY{k}{def} \PY{n+nf}{conv\PYZus{}layer}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{input\PYZus{}tensor}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{name}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{kernel\PYZus{}size}\PY{p}{,} 
                       \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}output\PYZus{}channels}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{padding\PYZus{}mode}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{SAME}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} 
                       \PY{n}{strides}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
            \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{variable\PYZus{}scope}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{name}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
                \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}\PYZsh{} get n\PYZus{}input\PYZus{}channels:}
                \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}\PYZsh{}   input tensor shape: }
                \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{}\PYZsh{}     [batch x width x height x channels\PYZus{}in]}
                \PY{n}{input\PYZus{}shape} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{input\PYZus{}tensor}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{get\PYZus{}shape}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{as\PYZus{}list}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}input\PYZus{}channels} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{input\PYZus{}shape}\PY{p}{[}\PY{o}{\PYZhy{}}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{]}
                
                \PY{n}{weights\PYZus{}shape} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n+nb}{list}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{kernel\PYZus{}size}\PY{p}{)} \PY{o}{+} \PYZbs{}
                                \PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{n\PYZus{}input\PYZus{}channels}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}output\PYZus{}channels}\PY{p}{]}
                    
                \PY{n}{weights} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{get\PYZus{}variable}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZus{}weights}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{weights\PYZus{}shape}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{weights}\PY{p}{)}
                
                \PY{n}{biases} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{get\PYZus{}variable}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZus{}biases}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} 
                                         \PY{n}{initializer}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{zeros}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{n\PYZus{}output\PYZus{}channels}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{biases}\PY{p}{)}
                
                \PY{n}{conv} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{nn}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{conv2d}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n+nb}{input}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{input\PYZus{}tensor}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n+nb}{filter}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{weights}\PY{p}{,} 
                                    \PY{n}{strides}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{strides}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{padding}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{padding\PYZus{}mode}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{conv}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n}{conv} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{nn}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{bias\PYZus{}add}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{conv}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{biases}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{net\PYZus{}pre\PYZhy{}activation}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{conv}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n}{conv} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{nn}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{relu}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{conv}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{activation}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
                \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{conv}\PY{p}{)}
                
                \PY{k}{return} \PY{n}{conv}
\end{Verbatim}


    This wrapper function will do all the necessary work for building a
convolutional layer, including defining the weights, biases,
initializing them, and the convolution operation using the
\emph{tf.nn.conv2d} function. There are four required arguments:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \emph{input\_tensor}: The tensor given as input to the convolutional
  layer
\item
  \emph{name}: The name of the layer, which is used as the scope name
\item
  \emph{kernel\_size}: The dimensions of the kernel tensor provided as
  tuple or list
\item
  \emph{n\_output\_channels}: The number of output feature maps
\end{itemize}

Notice that the weights are initialized using the Xavier (or Glorot)
initialization method by default when using \emph{tf.get\_variable},
while the biases are initialized to zeros using the \emph{tf.zeros}
function. The net pre-activations are passed to the ReLU activation
function. We can print the operations and TensorFlow graph nodes to see
the shape and type of tensors. Let's test this function with a simple
input by defining a placeholder, as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}9}]:} \PY{n}{g} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Graph}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
        \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{g}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{as\PYZus{}default}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
            \PY{n}{x} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{placeholder}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{float32}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{[}\PY{k+kc}{None}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{28}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{28}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}
            \PY{n}{conv\PYZus{}layer}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{x}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{convtest}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{kernel\PYZus{}size}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m+mi}{3}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{3}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} 
                       \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}output\PYZus{}channels}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{32}\PY{p}{)}
        \PY{k}{del} \PY{n}{g}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{x}
\end{Verbatim}

    The next wrapper function is for defining our fully connected layers:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}10}]:} \PY{k}{def} \PY{n+nf}{fc\PYZus{}layer}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{input\PYZus{}tensor}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{name}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}output\PYZus{}units}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{activation\PYZus{}fn}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{None}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{variable\PYZus{}scope}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{name}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
                 \PY{n}{input\PYZus{}shape} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{input\PYZus{}tensor}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{get\PYZus{}shape}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{as\PYZus{}list}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{:}\PY{p}{]}
                 \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}input\PYZus{}units} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{prod}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{input\PYZus{}shape}\PY{p}{)}
                 \PY{k}{if} \PY{n+nb}{len}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{input\PYZus{}shape}\PY{p}{)} \PY{o}{\PYZgt{}} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{:}
                     \PY{n}{input\PYZus{}tensor} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{reshape}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{input\PYZus{}tensor}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{o}{\PYZhy{}}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}input\PYZus{}units}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}
                     
                 \PY{n}{weights\PYZus{}shape} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{n\PYZus{}input\PYZus{}units}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}output\PYZus{}units}\PY{p}{]}
                 \PY{n}{weights} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{get\PYZus{}variable}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZus{}weights}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} 
                                           \PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{weights\PYZus{}shape}\PY{p}{)}
                 \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{weights}\PY{p}{)}
                 
                 \PY{n}{biases} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{get\PYZus{}variable}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZus{}biases}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} 
                                          \PY{n}{initializer}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{zeros}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{[}\PY{n}{n\PYZus{}output\PYZus{}units}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}
                 \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{biases}\PY{p}{)}
                 
                 \PY{n}{layer} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{matmul}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{input\PYZus{}tensor}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{weights}\PY{p}{)}
                 \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{layer}\PY{p}{)}
                 
                 \PY{n}{layer} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{nn}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{bias\PYZus{}add}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{layer}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{biases}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{net\PYZus{}pre\PYZhy{}activation}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
                 \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{layer}\PY{p}{)}
                 
                 \PY{k}{if} \PY{n}{activation\PYZus{}fn} \PY{o+ow}{is} \PY{k+kc}{None}\PY{p}{:}
                     \PY{k}{return} \PY{n}{layer}
                 
                 \PY{n}{layer} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{activation\PYZus{}fn}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{layer}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{activation}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}

    The wrapper function \emph{fc\_layer} also builds the weights and
biases, initializes them similar to the \emph{conv\_layer} function, and
then performs a matrix multiplication using the \emph{tf.matmul}
function. The \emph{fc\_layer} function has three required arguments:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \emph{input\_tensor}: The input tensor
\item
  \emph{name}: The name of the layer, which is used as the scope name
\item
  \emph{n\_output\_units}: The number of output units
\end{itemize}

We can test this function for a simple input tensor as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}11}]:} \PY{n}{g} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Graph}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
         \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{g}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{as\PYZus{}default}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{n}{x} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{placeholder}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{float32}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{[}\PY{k+kc}{None}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{28}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{28}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{n}{fc\PYZus{}layer}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{x}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{fc\PYZus{}test}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{n\PYZus{}output\PYZus{}units}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{32}\PY{p}{,} 
                      \PY{n}{activation\PYZus{}fn}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{nn}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{relu}\PY{p}{)}
         \PY{k}{del} \PY{n}{g}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{x}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
<tf.Variable 'fc\_test/\_weights:0' shape=(784, 32) dtype=float32\_ref>
<tf.Variable 'fc\_test/\_biases:0' shape=(32,) dtype=float32\_ref>

    The behavior of this function is a bit different for the two fully
connected layers in our model. The first fully connected layer gets its
input right after a convolutional layer; therefore, the input is still a
4D tensor. For the second fully connected layer, we need to flatten the
input tensor using the \emph{tf.reshape} function. Furthermore, the net
pre-activations from the first FC layer are passed to the ReLU
activation function, but the second one corresponds to the
\emph{logits}, and therefore, a linear activation must be used.

Now we can utilize these wrapper functions to build the whole
convolutional network. We define a function called \emph{build\_cnn} to
handle the building of the CNN model, as shown in the following code:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}22}]:} \PY{k}{def} \PY{n+nf}{build\PYZus{}cnn}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} Placeholders for X and y}
             \PY{n}{tf\PYZus{}x} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{placeholder}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{float32}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{[}\PY{k+kc}{None}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+m+mi}{784}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,} 
                                   \PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{tf\PYZus{}x}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{n}{tf\PYZus{}y} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{placeholder}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{int32}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{shape}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{[}\PY{k+kc}{None}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{,} 
                                   \PY{n}{name}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{tf\PYZus{}y}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}

    In order to get stable results, we need to use a random seed for both
NumPy and TensorFlow. Setting the TensorFlow random seed can be done at
the graph level by placing the \emph{tf.set\_random\_set} function
within the graph scope, which we will see later. The following figure
shows the TensorFlow graph related to our multiplayer CNN as visualized
by TensorBoard:

    Note that in this implementation, we used the
\emph{tf.train.AdamOptimizer} function for training the CNN model. The
Adam optimizer is a robust gradient-based optimization method suited for
nonconvex optimization and machine learning problems. Two popular
optimization methods inspired Adam: \emph{RMSProp} and \emph{AdaGrad}.

The key advantage of Adam is in the choice of update step size derived
from the running average of gradient moments.

Furthermore, we will define four other functions: \emph{save}, and
\emph{load} for saving and loading checkpoints of the trained model,
\emph{train} for training the model using \emph{training\_set}, and
\emph{predict} to get prediction probabilities or prediction labels of
the test data. The code for these functions is as follows:

{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}16}]:} \PY{k}{def} \PY{n+nf}{predict}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{return\PYZus{}proba}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{False}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{n}{feed} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{\PYZob{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{tf\PYZus{}x:0}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{:} \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{fc\PYZus{}keep\PYZus{}prob:0}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{:} \PY{l+m+mf}{1.0}\PY{p}{\PYZcb{}}
             \PY{k}{if} \PY{n}{return\PYZus{}proba}\PY{p}{:}
                 \PY{k}{return} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{run}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{probabilities:0}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{feed\PYZus{}dict}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{feed}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{k}{else}\PY{p}{:}
                 \PY{k}{return} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{run}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{labels:0}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{feed\PYZus{}dict}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{feed}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    Now we can create a TensorFlow graph object, set the graph-level random
seed, and build the CNN model in that graph, as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}23}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} Define hyperparameters}
         \PY{n}{learning\PYZus{}rate}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mf}{1e\PYZhy{}4}
         \PY{n}{random\PYZus{}seed} \PY{o}{=} \PY{l+m+mi}{123}
         
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} create a graph}
         \PY{n}{g} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Graph}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
         \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{g}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{as\PYZus{}default}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{set\PYZus{}random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} build the graph}
             \PY{n}{build\PYZus{}cnn}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
             
             \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} saver}
             \PY{n}{saver} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{train}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Saver}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

    Note that in the preceding code, after we built the model by calling the
\emph{build\_cnn} function, we created a saver object from the
\emph{tf.train.Saver} class for saving and restoring trained models.

The next step is to train our CNN model. For this, we need to create a
TensorFlow session to launch the graph; then, we call the \emph{train}
function. To train the model for the first time, we have to initialize
all the variables in the network.

For this purpose, we have defined an argument named \emph{initialize}
that will take care of the initialization. When \emph{initialize=True},
we will execute \emph{tf.global\_variables\_initializer} through
\emph{session.run}. This initialization step should be avoided in case
you want to train additional epochs; for example, you can restore an
already trained model and train further for additional 10 epochs. The
code for training for the first time is as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}27}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} create a TF session}
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} and train the CNN model}
         
         \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Session}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{graph}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{g}\PY{p}{)} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{n}{train}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{training\PYZus{}set}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}train\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y\PYZus{}train}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} 
                   \PY{n}{validation\PYZus{}set}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}valid\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y\PYZus{}valid}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} 
                   \PY{n}{initialize}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{True}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{123}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{n}{save}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{saver}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{epoch}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{20}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

    After the 20 epochs are finished, we save the trained model for future
use so that we do not have to retrain the model every time, and
therefore, save computational time. The following code shows how to
restore a saved model. We delete the graph \emph{g}, then create a new
graph \emph{g2}, and reload the trained model to do prediction on the
test set:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}28}]:} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} calculate prediction accuracy}
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} on test set}
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} restoring the saved model}
         
         \PY{k}{del} \PY{n}{g}
         
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} create a new graph }
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} and build the model}
         \PY{n}{g2} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Graph}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
         \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{g2}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{as\PYZus{}default}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{set\PYZus{}random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} build the graph}
             \PY{n}{build\PYZus{}cnn}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} saver}
             \PY{n}{saver} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{train}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Saver}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
             
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} create a new session}
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} and restore the model}
         \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Session}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{graph}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{g2}\PY{p}{)} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{n}{load}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{saver}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{epoch}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{20}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{path}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{./model/}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{n}{preds} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{predict}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{return\PYZus{}proba}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{False}\PY{p}{)}
             \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Test Accuracy: }\PY{l+s+si}{\PYZpc{}.3f}\PY{l+s+si}{\PYZpc{}\PYZpc{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}} \PY{o}{\PYZpc{}} \PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m+mi}{100}\PY{o}{*}\PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{sum}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{preds}\PY{o}{==}\PY{n}{y\PYZus{}test}\PY{p}{)}\PY{o}{/}\PY{n+nb}{len}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{y\PYZus{}test}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

    As you can see, the prediction accuracy on the test set is already
better than what we achieved using the multilayer perceptron.

Please, make sure you use \emph{X\_test\_centered}, which is the
preprocessed version of the test data; you will get lower accuracy if

    Finally, let's see how we can train the model further to reach a total
of 40 epochs. Since, we have already trained 20 epochs from the
initialized weights and biases. We can save time by restoring the
already trained model and continue training for 20 additional epochs.
This will be very easy to do with out setup. We need to call the
\emph{train} function again, but this time, we set
\emph{initialize=False} to avoid the initialization step. The code is as
follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} create a new session}
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} and restore the model}
         \PY{k}{with} \PY{n}{tf}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{Session}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{graph}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{g2}\PY{p}{)} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{:}
             \PY{n}{load}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{saver}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{epoch}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{20}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{path}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{./model/}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
             
             \PY{n}{train}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{training\PYZus{}set}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}train\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y\PYZus{}train}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} 
                   \PY{n}{validation\PYZus{}set}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}valid\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y\PYZus{}valid}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} 
                   \PY{n}{initialize}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{False}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{epochs}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{20}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{123}\PY{p}{)}
             
             \PY{n}{save}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{saver}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{epoch}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{40}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{path}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{./model/}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
             
             \PY{n}{preds} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{predict}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{sess}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{return\PYZus{}proba}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{False}\PY{p}{)}

In this section, we saw how to implement a multilayer convolutional
neural network in the low-level TensorFlow API. In the next section, we
will now implement the same network but we will use the TensorFlow Layer
API.

    \subsection{Implementing a CNN in the TensorFlow Layers
API}\label{implementing-a-cnn-in-the-tensorflow-layers-api}

    For the implementation in the TensorFlow Layers API, we need to repeat
the same process of loading the data and preprocessing steps to get
\emph{X\_train\_centered}, \emph{X\_valid\_centered}, and
\emph{X\_test\_centered}. Then, we can implement the model in a new
class, as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}36}]:} \PY{k+kn}{import} \PY{n+nn}{tensorflow} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n+nn}{tf}
         \PY{k+kn}{import} \PY{n+nn}{numpy} \PY{k}{as} \PY{n+nn}{np}
         
         \PY{k}{class} \PY{n+nc}{ConvNN}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n+nb}{object}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
             
             \PY{k}{def} \PY{n+nf}{\PYZus{}\PYZus{}init\PYZus{}\PYZus{}}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n+nb+bp}{self}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{batchsize}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{64}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{epochs}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{20}\PY{p}{,} 
                          \PY{n}{learning\PYZus{}rate}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mf}{1e\PYZhy{}4}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{dropout\PYZus{}rate}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PY{p}{,}

                             \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Validation Acc: }\PY{l+s+si}{\PYZpc{}7.3f}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}} \PY{o}{\PYZpc{}} \PY{n}{valid\PYZus{}acc}\PY{p}{)}
                         \PY{k}{else}\PY{p}{:}
                             \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{p}{)}
                             
             \PY{k}{def} \PY{n+nf}{predict}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n+nb+bp}{self}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{return\PYZus{}proba}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{False}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{:}
                 \PY{n}{feed} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{\PYZob{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{tf\PYZus{}x:0}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{:} \PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{is\PYZus{}train:0}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{:} \PY{k+kc}{False}\PY{p}{\PYZcb{}} \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} for dropout}
                 \PY{k}{if} \PY{n}{return\PYZus{}proba}\PY{p}{:}
                     \PY{k}{return} \PY{n+nb+bp}{self}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{sess}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{run}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{probabilities:0}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{feed\PYZus{}dict}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{feed}\PY{p}{)}
                 \PY{k}{else}\PY{p}{:}
                     \PY{k}{return} \PY{n+nb+bp}{self}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{sess}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{run}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{labels:0}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{feed\PYZus{}dict}\PY{o}{=}\PY{n}{feed}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    The structure of this class is very similar to the previous section with
the low-level TensorFlow API. The class has a constructor that sets the
training parameters, creates a graph \emph{g}, and builds the model.
Besides the constructor, there are five major methods:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \emph{.build}: Builds the model
\item
  \emph{.save}: To save a trained model
\item
  \emph{.load}: To restore a saved model
\item
  \emph{.train}: Trains the model
\item
  \emph{.predict}: To do prediction on a test set
\end{itemize}

Similar to the implementation in the previous section, we have used a
dropout layer after the first fully connected layer. In the previous
implementation that used the low-level TensorFlow API, we used the
\emph{tf.nn.dropout} function, but here we used
\emph{tf.layers.dropout}, which is a wrapper for the
\emph{tf.nn.drouput} function. There are two major differences between
these two functions that we need to be careful about:

\begin{itemize}
\tightlist
\item
  \emph{tf.nn.dropout}: This has an argument called \emph{keep\_prob}
  that indicates that probability of keeping the units, while
  \emph{tf.layers.dropout} has a \emph{rate} parameter, which is the
  rate of dropping units - therefore \emph{rate=1-keep\_prob}.
\item
  In the \emph{tf.nn.dropout} function, we fed the \emph{keep\_prob}
  parameter using a placeholder so that during the training, we will use
  \emph{keep\_prob=0.5}. Then, during the inference (or prediction)
  mode, we used \emph{keep\_prob=1}. However, in
  \emph{tf.layers.dropout}, the value of \emph{rate} is provided upon
  the creation of the dropout layer in the graph, and we cannot change
  it during the training or the inference modes. Instead, we need to
  provide a Boolean argument called \emph{training} to determine whether
  we need to apply droupout or not. This can be done using a placeholder
  of type \emph{tf.bool}, which we will feed with the value \emph{True}
  during the training mode and \emph{False} during the inference mode.
\end{itemize}

We can create an instance of the \emph{ConvNN} class, train it for 20
epochs, and save the model. The code for this is as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}37}]:} \PY{n}{cnn} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{ConvNN}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{random\PYZus{}seed}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{123}\PY{p}{)}
         
         \PY{c+c1}{\PYZsh{} train the model }
         \PY{n}{cnn}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{train}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{training\PYZus{}set}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}train\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y\PYZus{}train}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} 
                   \PY{n}{validation\PYZus{}set}\PY{o}{=}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}valid\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{y\PYZus{}valid}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{,} 
                   \PY{n}{initialize}\PY{o}{=}\PY{k+kc}{True}\PY{p}{)}
         \PY{n}{cnn}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{save}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{epoch}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{20}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

         \PY{n}{cnn2}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{load}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{epoch}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+m+mi}{20}\PY{p}{,} \PY{n}{path}\PY{o}{=}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{./tflayers\PYZhy{}model/}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{)}
         
         \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{cnn2}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{predict}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{[}\PY{p}{:}\PY{l+m+mi}{10}\PY{p}{,} \PY{p}{:}\PY{p}{]}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

    Finally, we can measure the accuracy of the test dataset as follows:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}39}]:} \PY{n}{preds} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{cnn2}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{predict}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{X\PYZus{}test\PYZus{}centered}\PY{p}{)}
         \PY{n+nb}{print}\PY{p}{(}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Test Accuracy: }\PY{l+s+si}{\PYZpc{}2f}\PY{l+s+si}{\PYZpc{}\PYZpc{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}} \PY{o}{\PYZpc{}} \PY{p}{(}\PY{l+m+mi}{100}\PY{o}{*}\PY{n}{np}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{sum}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{y\PYZus{}test}\PY{o}{==}\PY{n}{preds}\PY{p}{)}\PY{o}{/}\PY{n+nb}{len}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{y\PYZus{}test}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

    \end{Verbatim}

    The obtained prediction accuracy is 99.32 percent, which means there are
only 68 misclassified test samples!

This concludes our discussion on implementing convolutional neural
networks using the TensorFlow low-level API and TensorFlow Layers API.
We defined some wrapper functions for the first implementation using the
low-level API. The second implementation was more straightforward since
we could use the \emph{tf.layers.conv2d} and \emph{tf.layers.dense}
functions to build the convolutional and the fully connected layers.

    \section{Summary}\label{summary}

    In this chapter, we learned about CNNs, or convolutional neural
networks, and explored the building blocks that form different CNN
architectures. We started by defining the convolution operation, then we
learned about its fundamentals by discussing 1D as well as 2D
implementations.

We also covered subsampling by discussing two forms of pooling
operations: max-pooling and average-pooling. Then, putting all these
blocks together, we built a deep convolutional neural network and
implemented it using the TensorFlow API as well as the TensorFlow Layers
API to apply CNNs for image classification.

In the next chapter, we will move on to \textbf{Recurrent Neural
Networks (RNN)}. RNNs are used for learning the structure of sequence
data, and they have some fascinating applications, including language
translation and image captioning!
